repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Resolves #22318 when vim.lsp.buf.definition() subsequently jumps to multiple locations if more than one server responds.

Motivation: In case of multiple servers supporting the same lsp method, neovim should merge the results and handle them the same way it currently handles multiple results from a single server. This can reduce confusion by removing jumping to multiple locations without the user's action. In comparison vscode merges responses from its plugins/lsp servers and presents them to the user in a single picker. This is also partially solved in [lspsaga](https://nvimdev.github.io/lspsaga/definition/), where in `peek_definition` every result in opened in a separate float. 

I am uncertain whether this is the best place to handle the entire thing and open for feedback. As of opening this PR is in incomplete state as there are no tests or documentation. I did not go any further as I am not sure what would be a good way to pass multiple contexts in case the option `on_list` is set.

In the future the same approach can be applied to other methods such as `type_definition`, `declaration`, `implementation`, and the general idea of merging results from multiple servers for `hover`.

comment_data.body: We should still check if `options.on_list` is given here and invoke it if so. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25830 for context.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -76,8 +76,75 @@ end
 ---     - on_list: (function) |lsp-on-list-handler| replacing the default handler.
 ---       Called for any non-empty result.
 function M.definition(options)
+  options = options or {}
   local params = util.make_position_params()
-  request_with_options(ms.textDocument_definition, params, options)
+  local bufnr = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+
+  ---@param results table<integer, {error: lsp.ResponseError, result: lsp.Location|lsp.Location[]|lsp.LocationLink[]|nil}>
+  local function handler(results)
+    local client_id_to_items = {}
+    local total_items = 0
+    for client_id, v in pairs(results) do
+      if v.error == nil and v.result ~= nil then
+        -- first check for Location | LocationLink because
+        -- tbl_islist returns `false` for empty lists
+        if v.result.uri or v.result.targetUri then
+          local client = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id)
+          local items = util.locations_to_items({ v.result }, client.offset_encoding)
+          total_items = total_items + #items
+          client_id_to_items[client_id] = items
+        elseif vim.tbl_islist(v.result) then
+          local client = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id)
+          local items = util.locations_to_items(v.result, client.offset_encoding)
+          total_items = total_items + #items
+          client_id_to_items[client_id] = items
+        end
+      end
+    end
+
+    if total_items == 0 then
+      return
+    end
+
+    -- jump to the only response
+    if total_items == 1 then

@@ -76,8 +76,75 @@ end

+

+  local function handler(results)
+    local client_id_to_items = {}

+    for client_id, v in pairs(results) do
+      if v.error == nil and v.result ~= nil then
+        -- first check for Location | LocationLink because
+        -- tbl_islist returns `false` for empty lists
+        if v.result.uri or v.result.targetUri then
+          local client = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id)
+          local items = util.locations_to_items({ v.result }, client.offset_encoding)
+          total_items = total_items + #items
+          client_id_to_items[client_id] = items
+        elseif vim.tbl_islist(v.result) then
+          local client = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id)
+          local items = util.locations_to_items(v.result, client.offset_encoding)
+          total_items = total_items + #items
+          client_id_to_items[client_id] = items
+        end
+      end
+    end
+
+    if total_items == 0 then
+      return
+    end
+
+    -- jump to the only response
+    if total_items == 1 then

comment_data.body:
It's not clear for me from the original PR (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/19213) why the context was needed, so I'd be inclined to remove it completely.

The changes in this PR anyway should probably have a news.txt entry that mentions that it handles now multiple clients - and more importantly, that customization via the handler override will no longer work.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -76,8 +76,76 @@ end
 ---     - on_list: (function) |lsp-on-list-handler| replacing the default handler.
 ---       Called for any non-empty result.
 function M.definition(options)
+  options = options or {}
   local params = util.make_position_params()
-  request_with_options(ms.textDocument_definition, params, options)
+  local bufnr = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+
+  ---@param results table<integer, {error: lsp.ResponseError, result: lsp.Location|lsp.Location[]|lsp.LocationLink[]|nil}>
+  local function handler(results)
+    local client_id_to_items = {}
+    local total_items = 0
+    for client_id, v in pairs(results) do
+      if v.error == nil and v.result ~= nil then
+        -- first check for Location | LocationLink because
+        -- tbl_islist returns `false` for empty lists
+        if v.result.uri or v.result.targetUri then
+          local client = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id)
+          local items = util.locations_to_items({ v.result }, client.offset_encoding)
+          total_items = total_items + #items
+          client_id_to_items[client_id] = items
+        elseif vim.tbl_islist(v.result) then
+          local client = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id)
+          local items = util.locations_to_items(v.result, client.offset_encoding)
+          total_items = total_items + #items
+          client_id_to_items[client_id] = items
+        end
+      end
+    end
+
+    if total_items == 0 then
+      return
+    end
+
+    local items = {}
+
+    -- luacheck: ignore 512
+    for _, v in pairs(client_id_to_items) do
+      for _, v2 in ipairs(v) do
+        table.insert(items, v2)
+      end
+    end
+
+    local title = 'LSP locations'
+    if options.on_list then
+      assert(type(options.on_list) == 'function', 'on_list is not a function')
+      return options.on_list({
+        title = title,
+        items = items,
+        -- FIXME currently passing nil as items can come from multiple clients
+        -- need a better way to attribute items to context
+        context = nil,

comment_data.body: If the type annotation is correct, then `v.result` will never have a `targetUri` because it's part of `LocationLink`

comment_data.body:
With https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26694 merged you could add a type annotation for this:

```suggestion
  local function handler(results)
    ---@type table<integer, vim.lsp.util.LocationItem[]>
    local client_id_to_items = {}
```

+    local client_id_to_items = {}

comment_data.body: One reason having a corresponding context for each item is to understand which lsp the item is coming from. This can be a part of a custom display of multiple items and doesn't have to be supported in neovim itself. I think this makes sense similar to how you can enable display of diagnostics source.

comment_data.body: I wonder if providing the context via a separate API (similar to how you can get a client's information given its ID) would be easier/cleaner.

comment_data.body:
> One reason having a corresponding context for each item is to understand which lsp the item is coming from. This can be a part of a custom display of multiple items and doesn't have to be supported in neovim itself. I think this makes sense similar to how you can enable display of diagnostics source.


The current shape/structure won't let you do that because there's no association between a individual item and the context.


We'd either have to change the complete `on_list` parameter shape - which would be breaking, or add a `client_id` to each individual item.

Either way, this doesn't need to block this PR.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -76,8 +76,76 @@ end
 ---     - on_list: (function) |lsp-on-list-handler| replacing the default handler.
 ---       Called for any non-empty result.
 function M.definition(options)

   local params = util.make_position_params()

+  local function handler(results)

+    local total_items = 0
+    for client_id, v in pairs(results) do
+      if v.error == nil and v.result ~= nil then
+        -- first check for Location | LocationLink because
+        -- tbl_islist returns `false` for empty lists
+        if v.result.uri or v.result.targetUri then

+      return
+    end

+    local items = {}
+
+    -- luacheck: ignore 512
+    for _, v in pairs(client_id_to_items) do
+      for _, v2 in ipairs(v) do
+        table.insert(items, v2)
+      end
+    end
+
+    local title = 'LSP locations'
+    if options.on_list then
+      assert(type(options.on_list) == 'function', 'on_list is not a function')
+      return options.on_list({
+        title = title,
+        items = items,
+        -- FIXME currently passing nil as items can come from multiple clients
+        -- need a better way to attribute items to context
+        context = nil,

comment_regular_data.body:
I have thought more about the contexts for lsp results and it seems like there are a couple of potential solutions here

- Omit contexts completely, given that they are already [omitted in location_handler](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/8fb7419d7c5e2df3b792d18fa56f973088e69be2/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/handlers.lua#L425). Thus this won't be a regression.
- Make each item include the context of the lsp response. The only downside I see in this is that the items are of shape `setqflist-what` (see help) and this change would somewhat break this convention.

Besides this concern, I think functionality wise this PR is a good state. I am happy to do the same for type_definition, declaration, implementation, and references in the same PR or do it separately in different ones.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: waiting for reply from the author
labels.name: needs:response

title: fix(lsp): lsp.buf.definition() handles responses from multiple servers
